s0153: Feudal lords worried about Chu's strength.
s0154: And so Chu's nobility and royal relatives all plotted against Wu Qi.
s0155: When King Dao died, his clansmen and ministers rose in rebellion and attacked Wu Qi. He fled to the king's corpse and threw himself upon it.
s0156: His attackers then shot and stabbed Wu Qi, but their arrows also struck King Dao's body.
s0157: After the king's funeral, the crown prince ascended the throne and ordered the prime minister to execute everyone who had shot Wu Qi and also hit the king's corpse.
s0158: Those convicted of shooting Qi saw their entire clans exterminatedâ€”over seventy families perished.
s0159: The Grand Historian says: What ordinary people call military masters all cite Sun Tzu's thirteen chapters and Wu Qi's military methods. These are widely available, so I will not discuss them. Instead, I will examine what these men actually did and established.
s0160: As the saying goes: 'Those who can act may not be able to speak, and those who can speak may not be able to act.'
s0161: Sun Tzu's strategic planning against Pang Juan was brilliantly clear, yet he could not prevent his own mutilation.
s0162: Wu Qi told King Wu that virtue matters more than terrain, yet when he put this into practice in Chu, his harsh cruelty and lack of mercy cost him his life.
